block.p: G.M. Announces Turnaround Plan That Includes 5,000 More Job Cuts General Motors unveiled details of a three-year blueprint to revive its fortunes, including 5,000 job cuts on top of 25,000 previously announced. But analysts questioned whether the plan was enough, saying it lacked the speed and breadth that have helped major rivals stage comebacks. [Page A1.]
G.M. workers across the country met the news with a mixture of shock, resignation and frustration with the company's management. [C1.]

J.P. Morgan Chase to Offer Hedge-Like Fund In the latest sign that hedge funds are going mainstream, J.P. Morgan Chase is marketing a mutual fund, the Highbridge Statistical Mutual Fund, which will be overseen by Highbridge Capital Management, the $9 billion hedge fund firm that the bank acquired last year. Market Place. [C1.]

Barriers to the Top for Women in Advertising Despite their notable rise in the ad business, women have a long way to go, especially as creative directors, the people who are ultimately responsible for the output of an agency. [C1.]

Mentor Plans to Continue Pursuit of Medicis The cosmetic medical device company Mentor indicated that it would not take Medicis Pharmaceutical's blunt rejection of its unsolicited $2.2 billion takeover proposal as the final word. In Mentor's view, the benefits of joining its breast implant and liposuction equipment businesses with Medicis's anti-wrinkle drugs and prescription skin therapies are so clear that there is every reason to hope a deal will eventually be struck. [C4.]

Dow Average Closes at Highest Level Since March The Dow Jones industrial average rose 53.95 points, to 10,820.28, its highest close since March 10. The advance put the Dow into positive territory for the year. The S.& P. 500 added 6.58 points, to 1,254.85, and the Nasdaq gained 14.60 points, to 2,241.67. [C6.]

U.S. Bans Poultry Imports From British Columbia Federal agriculture officials banned poultry imports from mainland British Columbia after Canadian officials reported finding a duck at a poultry farm that was sick with the flu. [A20.]

Two Lawsuits Are Filed Against Sony BMG In separate actions, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a digital rights advocacy group in California, and the Texas attorney general filed lawsuits against Sony BMG, claiming it violated consumers' rights and traded in malicious software. [C6.]

America Online Makes Video Distribution Deal America Online reached an unusual arrangement with a start-up company that will allow almost any producer of video content to distribute programming on its service, splitting revenue from advertising or fees. [C15.]

Microsoft Plans to Make Software Formats Available Microsoft announced that it would seek approval to make the software formats behind its Office programs an ''open standard'' that it would license free to competitors, partners and developers. [C6.]

Intel and Micron Technology Plan Chip Venture Intel and Micron Technology announced a venture to manufacture NAND flash-memory chips in an effort to tap into one of the chip industry's fastest growing segments. [C6.]

Putin Agrees to Set Schedule for Pipeline to Japan Japan won a promise from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to establish within a year a construction timetable for a pipeline that would carry Siberian oil to the Sea of Japan. [A8.]

Capitalizing on Environmental Concerns Cargill is among a cadre of companies profiting from concerns -- by shareholders, communities and consumers alike -- about global warming, leaking landfills and other potential environmental woes. [C1.]

Goldman Sachs announced a policy that details how its 24,000 employees -- be they bankers, analysts or purchasing agents -- should promote activities that protect forests and guard against climate change. [C3.]

Google to Give $3 Million for Digital Library The Library of Congress is set to announce a $3 million gift from Google to help the library begin building a World Digital Library, a project that aims to digitize and place on the Web significant primary materials from national libraries and other institutions around the world. James H. Billington, left, the librarian of Congress, said the World Digital Library would be modeled after the library's American Memory Project, which has been digitizing and placing on the Web millions of historical artifacts. [C6.]

Google executives said that the company planned to move quickly to capitalize on its new Google Base database service, adding a feature that permits merchants to provide local shopping information. [C3.]
